info.name: HailJoe's Homebrew Spells
info.description: Newmade Homebrew Spells from the HailJoe.

element.name: Corpse Explosion
element.supports: Sorcerer, Warlock, Wizard, Spell Saving Throw

description.p: At your command, the lifeless body of a recently deceased creature swiftly swells and bursts into a horrifying explosion. You choose a corpse of a creature that has been lifeless for no more than 1 minute that you can see within range, triggering an explosion. Each creature within a 10-footradius sphere centered on that corpse must make a Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 3d6 necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The size of the explosion increases by 5 feet for every size larger than medium.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1st.

element.name: Shadow Bending
element.supports: Bard, Sorcerer, Wizard, Spell Saving Throw

description.p: You manipulate the shadow of a creature you can see within range according to your will. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or its shadow animates into a malevolent attacker. For the duration, the shadow stays attached to the target, sharing its space and constantly hindering it, granting advantage on all attacks against it. On each of your turns for the duration, you can use your action to deal 2d6 necrotic damage to the target automatically.
At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell ends on the target.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 2nd.

For the duration, you gain the ability to read non-magical texts at a rate of 100 pages per minute. After the spell has ended, you can remember the details of what you read as if you had read it normally with a clear mind. You must be able to comprehend the language in which a text is written in order to utilize this spell.
Additionally, you can combine this spell with any other spell that enables you to read and understand texts written in languages you don’t know.

setters.set: a book that is written at least 50 years ago and a small bag of coffee beans

description.p: You reach out and touch the corpse of a creature. Within a minute, the corpse rapidly begins to decompose. It becomes covered in fungi and mold, but during this process, no odor emanates. All the water in the body disappears, and at the end of the duration, only a handful of dust remains from the corpse.
The spell’s target corpse count increases when you reach 5th level 4, 11th level 16, and 17th level it becomes a pile of corpses with indefinite amount.
Using the instrument in your hand, you produce a simple sound. Within the range of the spell, at the location you pointed to, five barely visible, translucent ghostly figures appear.
These figures, aside from their pale colors, resemble well-dressed bards and play the songs you desire with perfect flawlessness throughout the duration.

You awaken the sense of mortality in one creature you can see within range. A construct or an undead is immune to this effect. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become frightened of you until the spell ends. If the save fails by 5 or more, the target also ages 1d4 × 10 years. The frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
The aging effect can be reversed with a greater restoration spell, but only within 24 hours of its occurrence. Otherwise, it can only be reversed with the "Wish" spell.

You spit a small amount of highly corrosive saliva to a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target on a hit the target takes 1d12 acid damage. On a roll of 1 you take the damage of the spell as the globe of acid explodes in your mouth.
At Higher Levels. This spell’s damage increases by 1d12 when you reach 5th level (2d12), 11th level (3d12), and 17th level (4d12).

You create a sudden eruption of acidic energy at a point you can see within range. Each creature within a 10-foot radius of that point must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 4d4 acid damage, and their skin is temporarily weakened, causing them to take an additional 1d4 acid damage at the start of each of their turns for the duration of the spell, or until they take an action to wipe off the acid. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and is not affected by the ongoing acid damage.

While you maintain concentration on this spell, you can use a bonus action on each of your turns to move the point of origin up to 30 feet in any direction. Any creature that starts its turn within the area of effect must make the initial Dexterity saving throw, even if they have already taken damage from the spell.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the initial damage increases by 1d4 for each slot level above 3rd. Additionally, the ongoing acid damage increases by 1d4 for each slot level above 3rd.

You point at a non-magical weapon within range and curse it with the bane of blades. The weapon begins to rust and corrode, losing its edge and becoming useless in combat. For the duration of the spell, targeted nonmagical weapons that are held by creatures or that are not being worn or carried take damage from rust and corrosion at the end of their wielder's turn. The number of turns a weapon can withstand this spell without breaking depends on the material of the weapon, as shown in the table below:

If a weapon's durability is reduced to zero, it is destroyed. If the wielder of a weapon affected by this spell leaves the area of the spell, the spell ends for the weapon, and the weapon reverts back to its undamaged version. If a weapon is destroyed before the end of the spell, it is destroyed permanently. Additionally, if a weapon is thrown or moved outside of the spell's area of effect, the spell ends on that weapon. You cannot target the same weapon multiple times with this spell, even if you cast it with a higher-level spell slot. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the number of weapons you can target increases by one for each spell slot level above 2nd.

element.name: Chain of Chill
element.supports: Cleric, Druid, Ranger, Wizard, Spell Saving Throw

description.p: You point at a creature and cause freezing cold chains to wrap around the target. The target makes a Dexterity saving throw on a fail; it takes 5d8 cold damage and gets restrained, on a success the target takes half damage and is not restrained.
The restrained target can, as an action, try to break free of the chains with an athletics check against the spell save DC of the caster.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 3rd.

You seek guidance from the fates by performing the ancient ritual of spilling molten lead into water. When you cast this spell, you heat up the lead until it becomes molten, and then pour it into the vessel of water

As the molten lead cools and solidifies in the water, it forms unique shapes and patterns that can be interpreted as omens or messages from the divine. You can make an Intelligence check to interpret the significance of the shapes and patterns, with the DC determined by the GM based on the complexity of the interpretation.

The interpretation can provide insight into a specific question or situation you are facing, or it can reveal general guidance or warnings. The interpretation is not always clear or definitive, and the GM has the final say on the outcome of the divination.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, you gain advantage on the Intelligence check to interpret the divination.

setters.set: molten lead and a vessel of water

description.p: You point your finger at a location within range, and the air around the air within 20 ft. of the point you choose becomes filled with acid particles floating mid-air. It lasts for the duration or until strong wind disperses the fog, ending the spell. Its area is heavily obscured.

When a creature enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must make a Constitution saving throw. The creature takes 8d4 poison damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures are affected even if they hold their breath or don't need to breathe.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the initial damage increases by 2d4 for each slot level above 4th.

You perform the ancient art of Haruspicina, using the entrails of a sacrificial animal to gain insight into the future. When you cast this spell, you must have access to the entrails of a recently deceased animal, which you use to divine the signs and portents of the future.

As you perform the divination, you toss the divination bones or knucklebones, interpreting the patterns and symbols they form to reveal information about future events. The GM provides you with information about potential events that could happen in the near future, such as battles, natural disasters, or political upheavals.

You can ask five specific questions about future events or seek general guidance on how to prepare for the future. The GM provides answers to these questions based on the results of the divination, although the answers may be cryptic or vague.

Roll a d100 to see the prophetic capabilities of the carcass you are inspecting. If you are using the carcass of a recently dead humanoid, you don't need to roll; the roll is assumed to be a 100 without a roll. Any carcass this spell is cast on cannot be revived with a spell below 7th level. Then roll an Insight check to interpret the results. Interpretation of the results gets harder as the depth of the knowledge you seek increases.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the number of questions you can ask increases by 1 for each spell slot above 7th level.

tr.td: Vague or ambiguous information, or information that is difficult to interpret or act on
General information about future events or circumstances, with some specific details
Specific information about future events, with clear details about time, place, and participants
Divine insight into the future, revealing hidden truths and secrets that are difficult to discover through other means

setters.set: a set of divination bones or knucklebones

description.p: As an action, you point your finger at a spellcaster. The spellcaster makes a concentration save against your spell save DC. On a failure, the target takes a d4 force damage per the number of spell slots it has.

Additionally, on a failure, the target loses 2d6 spell slots it has starting from the highest level available. If a target drops to 0 hit points as a result of this spell, it bursts into arcane flames and turns to ash.

You create a burst of healing energy that jumps from creature to creature. Choose a creature within range to be the first target of the spell. That creature regains hit points equal to 3d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier.

The spell then jumps to up to three other creatures of your choice within 30 feet of the first target, each of which regains hit points equal to 3d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier. The spell can jump to a total of four creatures, and each creature can only be targeted maximum twice.

If any of the creatures you target are undead, they take radiant damage instead of regaining hit points. These targets make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC. On a success, they receive half the damage. On a fail, the damage dealt is equal to the amount of healing they would have received.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the amount of healing increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 5th.

setters.set: a diamond worth at least 100 gp, which the spell consumes
